title: Indoor Sport Facility in Sudur Mjodd — Construction Supervision Services and Construction Manager for Owner — 14947
description: On behalf of the Department of Environment and Planning (USK), the purchasing department of Reykjavík City advertises for tenders for construction supervision services, for the construction of an indoor sport facility in South — Mjódd in Reykjavík. This tender includes construction supervision of the works involved, including but not limited to earthworks, concrete works, steel works, piping, electrical and other house systems as well as exterior and interior finishing including sports flooring and installation of fixed equipment. It also includes the services of construction manager for the owner. The main tasks are: • construction supervision, • duties of construction manager in accordance to Icelandic regulation No 112/2012, • reporting to owner, • liaison with construction regulatory bodies, • HSE monitoring.

lots.title: Indoor Sport Facility in Sudur Mjodd — Construction Supervision Services and Construction Manager for Owner
lots.description: On behalf of the Department of Environment and Planning (USK), the purchasing department of Reykjavík City advertises for tenders for construction supervision services, for the construction of an indoor sport facility in South — Mjódd in Reykjavík. All tenders will be reviewed and will be assessed based on the information they submit with their application and the tender price. The total size of the Indoor sport facility will be 4 220 m2, of which the sports hall for handball and basketball will be 2 400 m2 (65.5 x 36.5 m) and the remaining 1 820 m2 will contain various service space, including dressing rooms. The estimated number of spectators is 800. The house is expected to be constructed of concrete and steel covered with metal cladding. This tender includes construction supervision of the works involved, including but not limited to earthworks, concrete works, steel works, piping, electrical and other house systems as well as exterior and interior finishing including sports flooring and installation of fixed equipment. It also includes the services of construction manager for the owner. The name of the project is: indoor sport facility in Suður Mjódd — construction supervision services and construction manager for owner. The main tasks are: • construction supervision; • duties of construction manager in accordance to Icelandic regulation No 112/2012; • reporting to owner; • liaison with construction regulatory bodies; • HSE monitoring.

title: 14943 — Renewal of MP Traffic Controllers
description: The procurement office of the city of Reykjavík, on behalf of the city of Reyjavík and the road administration (Vegagerðin), requests participants in a tender for the renewal of MP traffic controllers, i.e. traffic controllers, detectors, signal heads and push buttons, according to further explanation in Chapter 2 – Product Description. MP traffic controllers have been in use in the capital area for several decades and are out of date, i.e. the producer doesn‘t support them any longer. It‘s almost impossible to provide replacement parts and the technical knowledge required for the controllers won‘t be available in the near future. The replacement of the MP traffic controllers is therefore an urgent safety issue. Offer should entail everything that is included with the product as it is defined in these tender documents. Offer should be made on the enclosed tender sheet. This is an open tender that is based on regulations surrounding public procurement no 120/2016.

title: Borgarlínan - Project Advisor
description: Borgarlínan is an exciting and transformational project which aims to implement a Bus Rapid Transit (‘BRT’) system in the Capital Area of Iceland. Borgarlínan is jointly proposed by the Association of Municipalities in the Capital Area, and Vegagerðin, the Icelandic Roads and Coastal Authority (together, the ‘Authority’). This contract notice relates to the Authority's requirement for a Project Advisor to act as its principal client-side advisor and project manager in respect of the Borgarlínan project.

lots.description: Borgarlínan is an exciting and transformational project which aims to implement a Bus Rapid Transit (‘BRT’) system in the Capital Area of Iceland. In order to meet carbon neutrality by 2040, Iceland has committed to significantly reduce the emission of green-house gases. Within the same timeframe, the population of the Capital Area in Iceland is expected to grow by around 28 % by 2040 (an increase of 60 000 people to 275 000). In order to address these issues, a new system of public transportation has been proposed, which would facilitate growth in an environmentally sustainable way and enable the population to travel shorter distances and in a more diverse manner with residential areas coalescing around transport hubs. This new system has been named the Borgarlínan, or, loosely translated, ‘City Line’. Borgarlínan is envisaged to be a gold‐standard BRT system, competitive with private transport but far more sustainable. It is expected to provide a rapid, safe, and comfortable trips for passengers, as well as to be recognisable by all Icelanders, with iconic stations and attractive buses, tied together under a common, familiar brand. As Borgarlínan is to be a modern BRT system, the current thinking is that it will be a third generation BRT. The proposed system will include a diversity of BRT routes, all branded under the Borgarlínan brand, but providing direct services for passengers, avoiding the need for a cumbersome transfer. Most of the Borgarlínan infrastructure will be constructed on the existing road network but several points, most notably a bike/pedestrian/and transit‐only bridge between Reykjavík and Kopavogur (Fossvogur Bay) and a new transit‐only bridge at Ellidaárvogur (Ellidaá Bay) will be newly constructed for use by the Borgarlínan. Specific stations and depot locations have not yet been evaluated. The current expectation is that construction of the infrastructure will commence in 2022. This contract notice relates to the Authority's requirement to appoint a Project Advisor to act as its principal client-side advisor and project manager in respect of the Borgarlínan project. Further detail on the specific role envisaged to be played by the Project Advisor is set out in the Project Information Memorandum (‘PIM’) accompanying this notice; however, at a high level, the Project Advisor may be expected to provide the following services: project management, project governance, data management, performance management and reporting, risk management, stakeholder engagement, political and regulatory engagement, financial management, change management, health/safety/wellbeing management, procurement support, ORAT, contract management, scheduling and logistics, design management, quality management and other related services. It is important to note that the Project Advisor will act as an independent body from all other advisors and contractors directly or indirectly involved in realising the Borgarlínan project. The very clear intention of the Authority is that the Project Advisor is its principal ‘client-side’ advisor on the project. Interested parties should therefore note that the Project Advisor shall not be eligible to be appointed to any other role/discipline connected to the Borgarlínan project, including as the Integrated Design Advisor, during the period of the Project Advisor's appointment.

deposits: The Authority may require a parent company guarantee and/or performance bond (as appropriate) as a condition of any contract to be awarded.

title: Facility Management System for the City of Reykjavik
description: The purpose of this RFI is to request information from potential bidders that are capable of providing a software solution for facility maintenance management. This currently published notice is a request for information only (RFI), but not a call for competition. There is no guarantee that this RFI will result in a competitive tender. Responding or not responding to this RFI will not affect any tender process. Parties should note that participation in this pre-market engagement exercise is not a prerequisite to participate in any possible subsequent procurement process. Reykjavik City is committed in ensuring that all parties are treated equally.

lots.description: Description of the procurement: The software solution needs to be able to manage diverse types of assets and equipment. The system should facilitate maintenance and monitoring work and enable users to record and organize maintenance in the most straightforward manner. The system needs to support and offer solutions in the following processes and solution areas: — registration of properties with precise location (GPS) and marking (QR code), as well as connection to a document database, — regular, preventive and incidental maintenance and inspections, — work recording with detailed information on resources, time, costs and assets, — planning, annual maintenance and contract-related maintenance, — reports, both standard and specific. It should be easy to set up reports and notifications in the system, — building/floor plans and layout display and management, — connections to external building/floor plan storage systems, — manuals and checklists, — alerts and notifications need to be available to keep track of process status and notify users when they need to respond to the system, — mail system connection, — connections to other systems and services, — role-based user access controls. The buyer is looking for a standardized software solution, preferably run as a software as a service, and a solution that offers an app for users. The operating environment is currently as follows: — number of users 300, — number of app users 200, — number of active assets 600, — approximate area of real-estates 500 000 m2, — approximate annual work orders created 15 000. Interested suppliers are requested to send in the following information: (a) name of system, version number and date of latest version; (b) testimonial of and referral to a current user with similar requirements and operating environment; (c) system environment, architecture, programming environment; (d) if hosted solution, in which country and describe the hosting (Cloud, SaaS, IaaS). Also describe how updates and patches are scheduled for the solution; (e) the size of the installation base, i.e. number of organizations using the system and size of those installs in number of users; (f) please provide a description of all currently supported services as well as a roadmap for future supported services; (g) description of the customer service level. Do you have local support in Iceland and what kind of services can be provided locally? (h) is your company ISO27001 certified and what other certifications do you have? (i) what web services/APIs for automation do you support? (j) what is your pricing model? (k) please provide an example of a service agreement; (l) please also provide a rough cost estimate for the software, set-up, implementation, training and license cost per year. Participants are welcome to share further information if available. To submit your documents, please go to the following tender portal and register your company: https://utbod.reykjavik.is/reykjavik/aspx/Home Please upload your documents to the tender portal — https://utbod.reykjavik.is/reykjavik/aspx/Home — before February 17th 2020 at 23:59.

title: Market Survey RFI — Digital Solution for the Reykjavík City Card and the Reykjavík Culture Card
description: Visit Reykjavík, on behalf of Reykjavik City Department of Culture and Tourism, is formulating a procurement process of a digital solution for the Reykjavík City Card and the Reykjavík Culture Card. A comprehensive solution for all service aspects and administration of the cards is requested: • cardholders' access to all entrance point; state- and city-owned museums, swimming pools, the Viðey ferry and public transport (Strætó); • sales at entrance- and sale points, online and through third parties; • the solution must be open architecture (API); • secure data collection and storage, in accordance with domestic and foreign law; • data collection includes visitor arrivals, sales, guest usage and use by time and date; • the solution should offer updates and developments.

lots.description: Visit Reykjavík, on behalf of Reykjavik City Department of Culture and Tourism, is formulating a procurement process of a digital solution for the Reykjavík City Card and the Reykjavík Culture Card. A comprehensive solution for all service aspects and administration of the cards is requested: • cardholders' access to all entrance point; state- and city-owned museums, swimming pools, the Viðey ferry and public transport (Strætó); • sales at entrance- and sale points, online and through third parties; • the solution must be open architecture (API); • secure data collection and storage, in accordance with domestic and foreign law; • data collection includes visitor arrivals, sales, guest usage and use by time and date; • the solution should offer updates and developments. Interested parties must be able to demonstrate all aspects of the offered solution. Further information about Reykjavík City Card can be found at citycard.is and Reykjavík Culture Card (Menningarkort Reykjavíkur) at menningarkort.is. Those who are interested should please contact the project manager of Reykjavík City Card, before 4 September 2020 at citycard@visitreykjavik.is Please note that this market research does not imply any obligation for future procurement, by neither the City of Reykjavík nor interested parties. It is not clear at this time when the procurement process will begin, but it will be carried out in accordance with the Public Procurement Act no. 120/2016 and the procurement rules of the City of Reykjavík.

title: Software Solution for Home Care Services
description: The welfare department of Reykjavík requests information about information system for home care services in relations to a possible forthcoming tender. The aim is to implement a quality software solution which meets the requirements of our future generation in social and home care. The core functionality of the system will be planning the services (around staff and tasks) and offering new type of digital services in the form of distance spanning solutions (for example video calls, smart devices and self-monitoring). Furthermore, we are looking for information about the possibilities of advanced service development within Reykjavík’s welfare department. There are three main questions, but feel free to include additional information. — what is the core functionality of your system solution? • name of system, version number and date of latest version; • does your solution have advanced staff and care planning? • what is your pricing model? • system environment, architecture, programming environment; — how does your solution offer digital and smart distance spanning solutions (social and/or medical)? — please provide, if possible, a description of all currently supported services (incl. web services/APIs) as well as a roadmap for future supported services. — how competent is your company regarding implementation and involvement of the development of new social and/or medical service? • the size of the installation base, i.e. number of organizations using the system and size of those installs in number of users.

description: The Icelandic Road and Coastal Administration (IRCA) requests bids for the widening Hringvegur (Ring Road, No 1) from Varmhólar to Vallá with a roundabout at MóaR and underpasses at Varmhólar and Saltvík, as well as construction of side roads and pedestrian sidewalks. The project is a collaboration between the Icelandic Road and Coastal Administration (IRCA), the City of Reykjavik, Veitur Utilities and Reykjavík Gagnaveita Reykjavíkur (fiber optic company).

lots.description: The Icelandic Road and Coastal Administration (IRCA) requests bids for the widening Hringvegur (Ring Road, No 1) from Varmhólar to Vallá with a roundabout at Móar and underpasses at Varmhólar and Saltvík, as well as construction of side roads and pedestrian sidewalks. The project is a collaboration between the Icelandic Road and Coastal Administration (IRCA), the City of Reykjavik, Veitur Utilities and Reykjavík Gagnaveita Reykjavíkur (fiber optic company). This is a widening of a 4.13-km long section of Hringvegur from Varmhólar to Vallá. The existing 2-lane road will be widened into 2 + 1 road with separate lanes. The work includes construction of a new roundabout, two underpasses made from steel plates, a resting place, and side roads. Soil compaction with the construction temporarily berms is part of the project on the road and future sidewalks along the side roads. The work includes culverts, rainwater pipes, road lighting, pipes for the Icelandic Road and Coastal Administrations information system, and pipe changes for the water supply companies. The estimated main quantities are: • fyllings (temporary berms) 230 000 m3; • fyllings 38 000 m3; • road cuttings, material to be disposed 88 000 m3; • rock cuttings 11 000 m3. Measurements plates and hoses (vertical soil displacement) 54 pcs. • subbase 64 000 m3; • roadbase 14 000 m3; • double surface dressing 30 000 m2; • cold-mixed asphalt 88 000 m2; • road safety cable barrier 4 200 m; • excavation 23 000 m3; • cold water pipes 3 700 m; • hot water pipes 3 550 m; • underground electric cables and wires 9 700 m.

title: Evacuation and Public Address Sound System (EVAC)
description: The project involves removal of Harpa's existing safety sound system (EVAC) and supply and installation of a new EVAC and PA system for the building (existing loudspeakers are reused), as well as tuning, tests and commissioning of the system. Detailed design and training of staff is also a part of the work.

lots.title: Evacuation and Public Address Sound System (EVAC)
lots.description: The project involves the renewal of Harpa's evacuation and notification sound system, a system commonly referred to as the Emergency Voice Alarm Communications (EVAC) system. In addition to EVAC updates a paging system shall updated and connected to the EVAC, so that sound from the paging system will be transmitted through EVAC amplifiers and speakers. EVAC is an emergency system that is connected to and is part of the building's fire alarm system. This system must meet all fire requirements and relevant standards as EN54, it is assumed that all new equipment that is installed and belongs to the EVAC part of the system will be according to EN 54. However, various equipment that will be re used and connected to a new system is not according to EN54. The system's speakers are an example of this. The system consists of cabinets, batteries, and power supply's approx. 78 power amplifiers and control units.

lots.description: The department of constructions and maintenance calls for tenders of project management service to coordinate and oversee all regular and incidental maintenance work for playgrounds in Reykjavik. The project manager has to ensure the safety and security standard which Reykjavik city provides. The main task are: • collecting deviations from the safety and security standard, • analysis of deviations, • project planning, • project execution, • project monitoring and control, • project closure. The project manager has to be in communication with different employees within the Reykjavik municipal and vendors on every stage of the project lifecycle. The department of constructions and maintenance uses a facility maintenance management system (FMMS) from MainManager to oversee the maintenance of the playgrounds. The FMMS divides the playgrounds into different categories. The categories are: • open spaces, • kindergartens, • schools. The project manager will work in the FMMS and use it to create tasks from deviations, execute tasks, monitor tasks and control the tasks. Key figures • 19 schools, • 40 kindergartens, • 89 open spaces.

title: Market Survey – Building and Operating Parking Facilities in Reykjavik — 14835
description: The purpose of the RFI is to request ideas and information from potential companies that are capable of building and operating centralised parking facilities as part of new development areas in Reykjavik. This currently published notice is a request for information only (RFI), but not a call for competition. There is no guarantee that this RFI will result in a competitive tender. Responding or not responding to this RFI will not affect any tender processes. Parties should note that participation in this pre-market engagement exercise is not a prerequisite to participate in any possible subsequent procurement process. Reykjavik Procurement Office is committed in ensuring that all parties are treated equally and the process will be carried out in full transparency.

lots.description: The City of Reykjavík (‘the City’) is redeveloping a new mixed-use development in areas/neighborhoods, such as Ártúnshöfði, Gufunes and Skerjafjörður. As part of the local plan process, the City is exploring the potential and feasibility of centralised parking facility (off-street parking) for the area, that would replace off-street parking in nearby developments (i.e. unbundled parking). The centralised parking facility would be within a reasonable walking distance from residential and commercial developments. The purpose of the RFI is to request ideas and information from interested developers that are capable of building and operating parking facilities in new neighborhoods in Reykjavik. More information about ongoing planning work In recent years there have been numerous new plans and proposals for new development areas in Reykjavík. Further information about these ideas and plans can be viewed in the RFI description and supporting documents. The City of Reykjavík’s expectations for centralised parking facilities. A centralised parking facility in an area can ensure that parking can be shared between residents, visitors and workers. As the parking facility will have a centralised location it is important that the building design offers attractive fronts and active street level, such as shops, services and/or restaurants and as appropriate and/or other usage such as a playground or viewing areas (public park), on the roof top. Tender terms for construction and operation. At the completion of the RFI process, The City aims to prepare tender terms for a parking facility in a suitable location as it will be proposed in new local plans. The tender will be issued for building rights to design, build, operate and finance a parking facility for a specific building lot. The operation of a facility will mostly involve managing parking but will also involve responsibility for operating or facilitating other services/uses of the building, if relevant. The developer will therefore have to consider the following at a minimum: • develop a business plan for the construction and operation costs; • develop ideas about operational arrangements, including parking management; • estimate reasonable construction time frame and methods; • secure funding for the project; • lead the design process, construction and operation of the parking facility, including managing the parking itself. Participants in the RFI It is anticipated that the first tender will be issued as early as this year, more may follow in the near future, based on the completion of local plans. Interested parties are invited to participate in the RFI by submitting information, suggestions and ideas regarding the project and tender terms no later than by the end of 19 June 2020. Submission documents from participants should at least include the following information: • general information regarding the participant, e.g. corporate/private ID-number, email address, etc.; • information about the participant, such as credentials and knowledge/experience regarding similar development projects. Interested parties are also offered to comment on one or more of the following items: (a) reasonable criteria that participants should satisfy in a competitive tender process for building and operating parking facilities; (b) the described scope of the project; (c) important criteria for centralised parking facilities regarding to design parameters, construction (e.g. time frame, cost range), operation and finance such as PPP (see more information in the RFI description and supporting documents); (d) ideas/suggestions that meet the City’s expectations regarding centralised parking facilities (see more information in the RFI description and supporting documents); (e) it might be possible to have commercial land use on the same building lot — or as part of the same building. Please state if and how this option will support funding to build and operate a parking facility.

description: The Icelandic Ministry of Transport and Local Government has the role to secure flight transport to and from Iceland while it can not be carried out for commercial purposes due to transport and travel restrictions because of the Covid-19 pandemic. Iceland as an island relies heavily on flight transport. Therefore the Ministry of Transport and Local Government plans to make a framework contract with one flight operator for flights between: • Iceland (Keflavík) and Boston (USA) and Envisaged duration of the contract is from 1 January 2021 to 31 March 2021 with the option to extend the contract twice – from 1 April to 31 May and from 1 June until 31 July 2021. The contract will cover 2 flights between Keflavík and Boston each week. The contract will be terminated as soon as commercial flights are up and running again. The framework contract will not secure a certain number of flights and certain flights will be decided with a short notice. The flight operator will not be entitled to a certain number of flights.

lots.description: The purchaser is looking to enter into contract for installation of AMI meters and is there for asking for applications for participation in a negotiated procedure for the beforementioned procurement. A pre-qualification process will be used to limit prospective participants to five (5), who will be invited to participate in the negotiated procedure. The purchaser intends to enter into full-scale rollout of smart meters for distribution systems for electricity, heat and water (water where applicable), in addition to the necessary software and communication solution. The total number of electricity meters is approximately 100 000, heat meters approximately 54 000 and water meters approximately 2 500. The total AMI project is divided into two main contracts: • the AMI Solution which contains all field equipment and the necessary software to operate the system that has already been tendered out (tender process VEV-2019-20 ongoing – contract notice 2019/S 098-238448); • the AMI Meter Installation (this procurement process). The scope of the AMI Installation project includes: • planning the works (for each of the defined milestone areas (MSA)); • all communications with end customers with regards to appointments for the installation of AMI meters; • installation of field equipment in each of the milestone areas (MSA); • work force management; • integration of the contractors appointment scheduling and workforce management system to the Purchasers internal systems; • warehousing and logistics for all field equipment; • optional — installation of communication infrastructure (TBD); • optional — clean-up; • optional — operational support (will be decided during the negotiation phase). The main objective of the negotiated procedure is to identify a contract for the AMI Meter Installation project best suited to comply with the purchasers needs and requirements as well as being the most economically advantageous according to the evaluation criteria.

lots.description: The department of constructions and maintenance calls for tenders of project management service to coordinate and oversee all regular and incidental maintenance work for playgrounds in Reykjavik. The project manager has to ensure the safety and security standard which Reykjavik city provides. The main task are: • collecting deviations from the safety and security standard, • analysis of deviations, • project planning, • project execution, • project monitoring and control, • project closure. The project manager has to be in communication with different employees within the Reykjavik municipal and vendors on every stage of the project lifecycle. The FMMS divides the playgrounds into different categories. The categories are: • open spaces, • kindergartens, • schools. The project manager will work in the FMMS and use it to create tasks from deviations, execute tasks, monitor tasks and control the tasks. Key figures • 21 schools, • 39 kindergartens, • 156 open spaces.

title: X-ray Diffractometer
description: This purchase is for an X‐ray diffractometer by the Science Institute, University of Iceland, to be located at the University of Iceland Nanotechnology and Materials Science Centre (UINC). The Centre is a collaboration between research groups working in experimental solid state physics, thin film physics and nanotechnologyat the University of Iceland and the UI Science Institute. UINC includes a cleanroom with lithography facilities,a strong arsenal of instrumentation and expertise for materials fabrication and structuring and facilities for materials analysis. The system comprises an X‐ray diffractometer and needed X‐ray optics for high resolution thin film structure analysis and standard powder diffraction. The primary fields of research intended for the instrument are condensed matter and thin film material science including the fabrication of thin film and layered materials and research on the structure of materials based research and chemical and phase analysis.

lots.title: X-ray Diffractometer
lots.description: This purchase is for an X‐ray diffractometer by the Science Institute, University of Iceland, to be located at the University of Iceland Nanotechnology and Materials Science Centre (UINC). The Centre is a collaboration between research groups working in experimental solid state physics, thin film physics and nanotechnologyat the University of Iceland and the UI Science Institute. UINC includes a cleanroom with lithography facilities,a strong arsenal of instrumentation and expertise for materials fabrication and structuring and facilities for materials analysis. UINC enables high level academic research for scientists at the University of Iceland and makes research within materials science and nanotechnology available to other research institutes in Iceland through collaboration as well as providing access for industrial partners. The system comprises an X‐ray diffractometer and needed X‐ray optics for high resolution thin film structure analysis and standard powder diffraction. The primary fields of research intended for the instrument are condensed matter and thin film material science including the fabrication of thin film and layered materials and research on the structure of magnetic materials, metallic films, semiconductor physics, oxides and nitrides and other solid state physics based research and chemical and phase analysis using powder diffraction. For this, the instrument contains the relevant and needed optical components, sample stages, control software,database of X‐ray data, X‐ray tube, detectors etc. The system enables future expansion of research capabilities via additional components (e.g. heating stages, new optical components etc.) Type of procedure Description of procurement The works/goods/services can be provided only by a particular tenderer for reasons that are: Technical The instrument to be acquired has a specific combination of capabilities and functionalities, as follows: — software controllable exchange between X-ray optics, allowing a range of different types of measurements to be automated in programmable batches, — a two-dimensional area detector capable of energy discrimination and high resolution data collection, — Dedicated X-ray optical components on both the incident and diffracted side for a full complement of high resolution X-ray diffraction analysis, — two beam paths on the diffracted side, one path to a two-dimensional area detector and the other to high resolution optics and a point detector. This allows automated switching between dedicated high and standard resolution configurations, — Eulerian cradle with phi and chi rotation, and XYZ stage with sizeable translation on all axes, over 10 mm in Z and over 50 mm in X and Y, — rotational spinner sample stage for powder diffraction in both reflection and transmission with the possibility of adding an automatic sample exchanger mechanism, — sample alignment camera setup, — analysis and simulation software, including materials database. Compatibility with existing equipment and expertise. The combined capabilities and functionalities are fulfilled only by the announced provider due to technical reasons. The possibility that there are other potential suppliers who could deliver the same at the available fixed price has been objectively excluded by market consultations.

title: Software Solution for Front-line Service Communication, 14664
description: The IT service department of Reykjavik City is requesting offers for a software solution to cover/host all communication channels between Reykjavik service center and its customers through phone, email and chat channel. Offers should cover all cost regarding the system, such as, server and client software, hardware, licences, installation, training, hosting and operational services throughout the contract lifetime. Offers should also include services to buyer and ongoing development of the system as well as taking down the system when the contract has reached its end date and delivering all data. Bidder should specify the type of software agreement, that is, if it is perpetual licence or subscription software licence. Bidder can only deliver one offer for one or more systems. The system should be software, hardware and operational services.

title: School Furniture — 15036
description: The Reykjavík School and Leisure Department requests bids for student furniture for compulsory schools, for children from the age of 6 years old to 16 year old.

lots.description: This tender covers the following: student chairs, student chairs adjustable in height, one-person student desk and student table for two people. It is based on furniture production that meets the standards for furniture production and has certifications to that effect. As the tender is for many schools, the choice of colour and height of furniture will vary from school to school. The sizes and types of furniture should be suitable for students. Sizes given in the furniture description are for reference only. The furniture, however, must be light and manageable and that strength and stability are paramount. Before the start of construction/ordering, the seller shall submit samples of the colour and hard plastic for the buyer's approval. Frame lacquering of lacquered furniture shall be lacquered for at least three coats with strong, semi-matte, approved lacquered lacquer or equivalent lacquer approved by the buyer. All welds on steel frame racks shall be ground and all corners rounded. There should be no visible joints on the frame of the chairs.

title: Single-molecule Confocal Fluorescence Microscope for Uni. Iceland
description: An RFI was created to give interested suppliers the opportunity to provide information a potential system that UI would purchase. The number 1 criteria was demonstrated single-molecule sensitivity. Three potential suppliers replied: PicoQuant (PQ, Berlin, Germany), Medor (Iceland) and Inter (Iceland). The instrument fromInter, Elyra 7, is not a confocal microscope and therefore not capable of the majority of experiments required (time-domain FLIM, TCSPC, FCS, smFRET and even STED). The MT200 from PQ is the only instrument that provides all specifications of the RFI in a single instrument and demonstrates excellent support and experience. Given the prime requirement of single-molecule sensitivity, the MT200 is the strongest instrument on the market.

lots.title: Single-molecule Confocal Fluorescence Microscope for Uni. Iceland
lots.description: Introduction An RFI was created to give interested suppliers the opportunity to provide information a potential system that UI would purchase. The number 1 criteria was demonstrated single-molecule sensitivity. Three potential suppliers replied: PicoQuant (PQ, Berlin, Germany), Medor (Iceland) and Inter (Iceland). The instrument from Inter, Elyra 7, is not a confocal microscope and therefore not capable of the majority of experiments required (time-domain FLIM, TCSPC, FCS, smFRET and even STED). Thus, here we discuss only the offers from PQ and Medor, based on the documents provided. Point-by-point PQ sells the MicroTime 200 (MT200), an instrument that addresses every point that was raised in the RFI. The MT200 is the only device that can offer all mentioned functions and answer question (a) of the RFI with comply. Other suppliers could only partially fulfill the required specifications. Medor sells the Olympus FV300, a laser scanning microscope (LSM) and they claim to be able to fulfill all requirements but only with an upgrade in collaboration with PQ. Single-molecule sensitivity The number 1 requirement that the instrument needs to fulfill is single-molecule sensitivity. For single-molecule sensitivity, the MT200 is the best suited system, as it is dedicated to those applications. To achieve highest sensitivity within the MT200 the number of optical elements has been reduced to a minimum. Detection is done free-space for best sensitivity and not via multimode fiber like with LSM (Medor) techniques where higher losses of photons occur. Another adaption in the MT200 for single-molecule sensitivity is a slightly expanded point spread function size, that guarantees the observation single-molecule bursts and optimal gaussian beam shape. This is done via a slight underfilling of the back aperture of the objective. This is in contrast to overfilling the back aperture, as in standard confocal LSMs (Olympus, ZEISS,...), where the main goal is maximal spatial resolution. PQ works closely together with Olympus (FV3000 f.e.), Zeiss (LSM series) and Nikon when it comes to upgrading their confocal microscopes with time resolved fluorescence. However, while fluorescense lifetimes add powerful additional information to LSMs and works nicely for cell biology applications, for single-molecule sensitivity a dedicated system is an absolute must. The MT200 is an accessible, modular system with maximum access and free choice of filters and main dichroics for optimal performance. For LSMs like FV3000, access is very limited and additional dichroics might be very expensive. Software In terms of user-friendliness: the MT200 has 1 software for both data acquisition and data analysis whereas with Olympus and Zeiss there would at least be 2 different software platforms required. Other specifications from RFI: — calibrated photo diode allowing calculation of laser power at objective (only PQ), — CCD‐camera‐based monitoring of back-scattered excitation light for focusing onto single-molecule samples as well as easy alignment of the system (only PQ), — possibility of using up to 6 detection channels with single-photon avalanche detectors (SPADs) (only PQ. PQ offers upgrades in FV3000 to 4 detection channels only), — options of super‐resolution microscopy (STED, FLIM‐STED, STED‐FCS), dual‐focus FCS (2fFCS), AFM and optical tweezers, with demonstrated success shown by systems in the field – Only PQ has demonstrated successful implementation of AFM and optical tweezers. PQ can offer STED but Olympus and Zeiss need other companies to provide this. Dual-focus FCS is only provided by PQ. Experience PQ have over 20 years of experience with time-resolved confocal microscopy and they provided an extensive list of customers worldwide. They also offer user trainings and scientific workshops regularly. It is unclear at this point what the scientific experience or customer base is for Medor. Conclusion The MT200 from PQ is the only instrument that provi

title: Hringvegur (1) over Jökulsá in Sólheimasandur
description: The Icelandic Road and Coastal Administration (IRCA) requests bids for the construction of a new bridge over Jökulsá river in Sólheimasandur.

lots.description: The work involves the construction of a new bridge that replaces an existing one-lane bridge. This new bridge is post-tensioned reinforced concrete in five spans. The total length of the bridge is 163 m and the total width is 10 m. The project includes 685 m of road construction and the width of the road is 8 m. The center line the new bridge will remain the same as on the existing bridge. Abutments and intermediate supports of the existing bridge will be demolished down to the foundations. The foundations will be re-used along with the erosion protection of the intermediate supports. New abutments will be reinforced concrete and the existing erosion protection will also be re-used. The estimated main quantities are: • road construction; • fillings 27 000 m3; • unusable material for disposal 29 000 m3; • subbase 11 280 m3; • roadbase 3 000 m3; • single surface dressing 6 900 m2; • double surface dressing 8 800 m2; • stone protection 500 m3; • road safety guard rail, installing 532 m; • demolish two bridges; • bridge Construction; • excavation 3 200 m3; • fillings around construction 1 440 m3; • formwork 3 970 m2; • reinforcement steel 304 T; • post-tensioning cables 28 T; • concrete 2 136 m3; • guard rail 324 m.

title: Market Survey – Purchase of Snow-Making Equipment for the Reykjavik Capital Area Ski-Areas
description: The purpose of this RFI is to request information from providers that are capable of giving information of technological analysis for the design of snow-making equipment including the associated system and constructions. This currently published notice is a request for information only (RFI), but not a call for competition. There is no guarantee that this RFI will result in a competitive tender. Responding or not responding to this RFI will not affect any tender process. Parties should note that participation in this pre-market engagement exercise is not a prerequisite to participate in any possible subsequent procurement process. Reykjavíkurborg is committed in ensuring that all parties are treated equally.

lots.description: The Reykjavik Capital Area Ski-Areas have plans of investing in snow-making equipment for the ski areas at Bláfjöll and Skálafell and this notice is a request for information only (RFI) but not a call for competition. The project involves the design and provision of a complete snow making system. Water for the manufacture in the Bláfjöll area is sourced from a groundwater borehole, provided by the buyer, with output of approximately 20 l/s. In Skálafell the water supply shall be collected from nearby creeks and water collection is included in the project. The snow-making system shall be connected and the system thence installed to a 12 000 m3 reservoir. The project involves the design and final finish of a reservoir, pump/control centre building and the snow-making system as a whole. The system shall be designed for at least 65 l/s and produce snow for the priority areas in Skálafell and Bláfjöll, with possibilities for extensions at a later date. Design, planning and equipment selection should consider the following conditions: — temp oC +1 to -4 50 %, — temp oC -4 to -7 30 %, — temp oC < -7 20 %, — wind (Bláfjöll / Skálafell) —— wind 0-5 m/s 20 %/30 %; —— wind 5-10 m/s 50 %/40 %; —— wind > 10 m/s 30 %/30 %. For more information about this project and to submit your response, please visit the Reykjavik City Tender portal at: https://utbod.reykjavik.is Providers are requested to send information about their experience and/or opinion on the following: — which design standards are traditionally used, or should be used, for referral regarding such snow-making equipment, their systems and their associated buildings? — when it comes to the testing of the provided equipment after installation, which standards and/or requirements should the snow-making equipment and the associated system fulfil to ensure both safe and reliable operations? — what would be the optimal solution regarding the pumping system in each case i.e. on one hand for the borehole in Bláfjöll and on the other hand for the water collection at Skálafell? — what would be the optimal solution for the structure and the external and internal finishing of the pump/control central building? — what would be the optimal solution for the laying of electrical cables, communication cables and water pipes? — what is a reasonable timeframe from start to finish for of this kind of project, i.e. divided between design, manufacturing and installation? — what would be a reasonable qualification criteria that participants in a competitive tender process for the project should meet? — any other suggestions in the intended preparation for a competitive tender process that could to be carried out or should beware of?

title: Iceland Air Transport Service
description: The Icelandic Ministry of transport has the role to secure flight transport to and from Iceland while it can not be carried out for commercial purposes due to transport and travel restrictions because of the Covid-19 pandemic. Iceland as an island relies heavily on flight transport. Therefore the Ministry of Transport plans to make a framework contract with one flight operator for flights between: — Iceland (Keflavík) and Boston USA; and — Iceland (Keflavík) and Stockholm in Sweeden; and — Iceland (Keflavík) and London UK.

buyers.name: Ministery of Transport and Local Government

lots.description: The Icelandic Ministry of transport has the role to secure flight transport to and from Iceland while it can not be carried out for commercial purposes due to transport and travel restrictions because of the Covid-19 pandemic. Iceland as an island relies heavily on flight transport. Therefore the Ministry of Transport plans to make a framework contract with one flight operator for flights between: — Iceland (Keflavík) and Boston USA; and — Iceland (Keflavík) and Stockholm in Sweeden; and — Iceland (Keflavík) and London UK. Envisaged duration of the contract is from 15th of May to the end of June with the option to extend the contract twice — from 1st of July to the 15th of August and from 16th of August until the end of September 2020. The plan is to have two flights between Keflavík and Boston in a week and 2-4 flights between Keflavík and London and/or Stockholm in a week. The contract will be terminated as soon as commercial flight will be up and running again. The framework contract will not secure a certain number of flights and certain flights will be decided with a short notice. If the situation will change in Scandinavia the flight operator shall be ready to fly to other destinations than Stockholm in Scandinavia — that is Oslo or Copenhagen instead of Stockholm. The flight operator will not be entitled to a certain number of flights.

title: Market Survey – Purchase and Installation of Ski Lifts for the Reykjavik Capital Area Ski-Areas
description: The purpose of this RFI is to request information from providers that are capable of giving information of technological analysis for the design of ski-lifts and their equipment. This currently published notice is a request for information only (RFI), but not a call for competition. There is no guarantee that this RFI will result in a competitive tender. Responding or not responding to this RFI will not affect any tender process. Parties should note that participation in this pre-market engagement exercise is not a prerequisite to participate in any possible subsequent procurement process. Reykjavíkurborg is committed in ensuring that all parties are treated equally.

lots.description: The Reykjavik Capital Area Ski-Areas have plans of installing new ski lifts at their ski-area in Bláfjöll and this notice is a request for information only (RFI) but not a call for competition. The project involves the design of lifts and their equipment, together with chair storages, manufacturing, installation, warranty maintenance for 2 years for equipment. Also, earthworks and foundations, casting and finishing of chair storages and finishing of surface. The slopes of Bláfjöll are loose gravel screes/weathered sediment with underlying pillow lava. At the bottom of the flanks of Bláfjöll the thickness of the scree layer is approximately 2-3 m, while further up it gets thinner and there is sporadic exposed bedrock visible on the surface. The pillow lava and uppermost part of the lava/dolerite covering can generally be excavated by powerful diggers larger than 35 tonnes. The boundaries between loose layers and bedrock can be unclear. At greater depths, the bedrock/tuff becomes denser and may require chiselling. The weather conditions in Bláfjöll is fairly rainy, with high winds. Snow depths and weather conditions in general vary considerably between years. As a rule, one can expect the snow to have disappeared from the Bláfjöll area by the end of May. The first night frosts begin in September, and October sees the first snowfalls, with quite long thaw spells in between. The provisional main specifications for the two ski-lifts are as follows: New chairlift — Gosi Lift type: Chairlift 4-seater (detachable) Throughput: up to 2 400 persons per hour Length: ~450 m Height difference: ~160 m Loading gate: yes Storage building for chairs: yes Speed: 5 m/s Transportation, load on lift: 100 % up and 25 % down New chairlift — drottning Lift type: chairlift 4-seater (detachable) Throughput: up to 2 400 persons per hour Length: ~1 110 m Height difference: ~220 m Loading gate: yes Storage building for chairs: yes Speed 5 m/s Transportation, load on lift: 100 % up and 25 % down Providers are requested to send information about their experience and/or opinion on the following: — which design standards are traditionally used, or should be used, for referral regarding such ski-lifts, their equipment and their associated buildings? — when it comes to the testing of the provided lifts after installation, which standards and/or requirements should the ski-lifts fulfil when it comes to the testing of load, operations, brakes, electricity etc., to ensure both safe and reliable operations? — the housing for the drive machinery, chair guides and etc. needs to be as weather tight as possible. What would be the optimal way to achieve the best results in this regard? — how is prevention against corrosion of the ski-lift equipment best achieved in such an aggressive environment and weather conditions? — what would be the optimal solution for the laying of electrical and communication cables? — should they be placed underground or are there some safe end secure solutions available for placing them above ground? — What would be the optimal solution for the structure and the external and internal finishing of the chair storage? — what is a reasonable timeframe from start to finish for of this kind of project, i.e. divided between design, manufacturing and installation? — what would be a reasonable qualification criteria that participants in a competitive tender process for the project should meet? — any other suggestions in the intended preparation for a competitive tender process that could to be carried out or should beware of? For more information about this project and to submit your response, please visit the Reykjavik City Tender portal at: https://utbod.reykjavik.is

description: The City of Reykjavík invites members of the EEA to submit tenders for the project ‘Urban Street Design in Árbær, Reykjavík — Preliminary Design.’ The project includes preliminary design of two street segments of Rofabær and Bæjarbraut streets, along with cycle paths and pavements, four public spaces and creation of tender documents for a detailed design for a given part of the preliminary design. All solutions must be environmentally sound and meet the current social norms of sustainability, usability and aesthetics. Bidder is to offer a multidisciplinary team of designers; including but not necessarily limited to: landscape architect, specialist in city planning and/or design, transport engineer or technologist, architectural lighting designer, acoustical engineer and artist.

title: Destination Iceland
description: Promote Iceland is looking for partners to collaborate on a new integrated marketing initiative for Iceland as a travel destination. Ríkiskaup, on behalf of Íslandsstofa (e. Promote Iceland), Sundagardar 2, 104 Reykjavik, ID-No 690986-1599, hereinafter purchaser, hereby invite tenders to participate in this invitation to tender (ITT). This ITT is an accelerated open procedure. Due to Covid-19 the purchaser and Ríkiskaup belives that reasons for an accelerated procedure are met. The categories of this ITT are the following: • concept and strategy, • public relations, • design and production of marketing material.

lots.description: The contract period is 1 year from acceptance of a tender with the possibility of an extension. A two (one year) contract extensions are subject to acceptance of the Parliament of Iceland (Alþingi) for further funding of the project beyond the year 2020. The Parliament of Iceland has already approved initial funding for the initiative of 1 500 m ISK for 2020 and the contract extensions are therefore subjected to the acceptance of the Parliament of Iceland. The request for the proposal is for the following categories for the destination Iceland: • concept and strategy, • public relations, • design and production of marketing material. The project will start when a binding contract is considered to have been established.

title: Reykjanesbraut (41) Krýsuvíkurvegur — Hvassahraun, MÁU — hönnun
description: The Icelandic Road and Coastal Administration (IRCA) requests a tender for Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA), preliminary design and full project design for the widening of Reykjanesbraut Highway(41), from the intersection at Krýsuvíkvegur road to the end of four lanes west of Straumsvík in Hvassahraun area.

lots.description: The Icelandic Road and Coastal Administration (IRCA) requests a tender for Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA), preliminary design, and full project design for the widening of Reykjanesbraut Highway(41), from the intersection at Krýsuvíkvegur road to the end of four lanes west of Straumsvík in Hvassahraun area. The project involves widening the existing Reykjanesbraut to the south, design one new intersection, one tunnel for pedestrians and cyclist, a new road connection to Straumur, and a road connection to the municipality's sewage pumping station east of Straumsvík. The length of the Reykjanesbraut section is approximately 5.6 km. Qualification and price decides the choice and the tenderer must send his bid in two parts, i.e. (1) information on bidder eligibility, (2) and price bidding. The work must be completed in full on 1 February 2022. Tender will be opened in two stages 22 July 2020 and 11 August 2020.

title: UHPLC-MSMS System for University of Iceland
description: The Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology, University of Iceland (DPTUI) owns and operates two UPLC-MS/MS instruments from Waters AB, Sweden. One robust Acquity I-class HPLC with a TQD detector and one more sensitive Acquity I-class HPLC with a TQS-μ detector. On the more sensitive instrument, two methods for analyzing blood samples and one method for analyzing urine samples are currently run on the system. More methods need to be developed for urine, blood, and other biological matrices to keep up with modern trends in toxicology. Waters has exclusive rights on the UPLC-MSMS system; it is protected both by patents and copyright. These rights have not been licensed to other producers of LC/MSMS systems. The software platform, MassLynx, is unique in its design vs other instrument manufacturers. No other high-end LC/MSMS can operate in such an environment and MassLynx is only capable of controlling Waters LC/MS and LC/MSMS systems.

title: Monolith LabelFree Microscale Thermohoresis (MST) for Uni. Iceland
description: An RFI was sent out to find interested suppliers and only one replied, NanoTemper Technologies GmbH. microscale thermophoresis technology from NanoTemper is integrated in the monolith systems. The monolith instruments utilize sample fluorescence to rapidly and easily determine binding affinity constants (Kd). The instruments are maintenance-free, have low running costs and use an intuitive software user interface. The Monolith NT.LabelFree measures MST using intrinsic tryptophan fluorescence and offers truly label-free conditions. Taken together the MST technology, which the the instrument is based on, requires less sample, is faster, is less intrusive and cost less than most binding analysis instruments.

The instrument needs to feature small cavity for fast sample turnover. The instrument needs to include proprietary wavelength monitor (WLM) controls laser for wavelength to within 2 MHz for precise quantification of spectral features. Analyser of the instrument is subjected to and must pass: mil-spec drop test; vibration test on both axes And Analyser of the instrument is subjected to and must pass: mil-spec drop test; vibration test on both axes; and environmental chamber test. The system needs to include an automatic preparation system for acidification of solid carbonates and DIC in water. The system needs to include a feature for low to high CO2 concentration (200-4000 ppm) for isotope analysis in air and N2 and a closed system pump for sample.

The system needs to include a feature for low to high CO2 concentration (200-4000 ppm) for isotope analysis in air and N2 and a closed system pump for sample circulation. title: Borgarlinan Integrated Design Advisor
description: Borgarlínan is an exciting and transformational project which aims to implement a Bus Rapid Transit (‘BRT’) system in the Capital Area of Iceland. Borgarlínan is jointly proposed by the Association of Municipalities in the Capital Area, and Vegagerðin, the Icelandic Roads and Coastal Authority (together, the ‘Authority’). This contract notice relates to the authority's requirement for an Integrated Design Advisor ('IDA') to act as its principal design consultant in respect of the Borgarlínan project.

lots.description: Borgarlínan is an exciting and transformational project which aims to implement a Bus Rapid Transit (‘BRT’)system in the Capital Area of Iceland. In order to secure carbon neutrality by 2040, Iceland has committed to significantly reduce the emission of green-house gases. Within the same time frame, the population of the Capital Area in Iceland is expected to grow by around 28 % by 2040 (an increase of 60 000 people to 275 000).In order to address these issues, a new system of public transportation has been proposed, which would facilitate growth in an environmentally sustainable way and enable the population to travel shorter distances and in a more diverse manner with residential areas coalescing around transport hubs. This new system has been named the Borgarlínan or, loosely translated, ‘City Line’. Borgarlínan is envisaged to be a gold‐standardBRT system, competitive with private transport but far more sustainable. It is expected to provide rapid, safe and comfortable trips for passengers, as well as to be recognisable by all Icelanders, with iconic stations and attractive buses, tied together under a common, familiar brand. The proposed system will include a diversity of BRT routes and infrastructure, all branded under the Borgarlínan brand, but providing direct services for passengers, avoiding the need for a cumbersome transfer. Most of the Borgarlínan infrastructure (bus lanes and stations) will be constructed on the existing road network but several points (including new bridges) will be newly constructed for use by the Borgarlínan. The current expectation is that construction of the infrastructure will commence in 2022. This contract notice relates to the authority's requirement to appoint an IDA to act as its principal design consultant, in particular in respect of Phase 1 of the Borgarlínan project which is more fully described in the project information memorandum (‘PIM’) accompanying this notice. Further detail on the specific role envisaged to be played by the IDA is set out in the PIM; however, at a high level, the IDA may be expected to provide some or all of the following services: civil engineering/transportation engineering, transport planning services and modelling, public transport network design, sustainable urban design/architecture,landscape architecture, sustainable technology services, accessibility consultancy services, civil engineering/structural engineering, geotechnical engineering, environmental consultancy services, signal control design, street lighting design, electrical services engineering, environmental acoustics consultancy services, urban planning/planning consultancy services, Breeam/Ceequal consultancy services, BIM consultancy services and other related services.

deposits: The authority may require a parent company guarantee and/or performance bond (as appropriate) as a condition of any contract to be awarded.
